questions.text:
Which of the following are functions of oxytocin?
  1. Milk ejection
  2. Milk production
  3. Milk storage
  4. Facilitation of labor
  5. Osmoregulation
questions.solution:
Oxytocin plays a role in milk ejection. It also helps in initiation or facilitation of labour by stimulating the contraction of uterine smooth muscles.

It stimulates postpartum milk let-down in response to suckling. 

Prolactin is the hormone responsible for milk production. 

Osmoregulation is mediated by hormones such as ADH, aldosterone, etc.

questions.text: Where are arginine vasopressin (AVP) and oxytocin stored?
questions.solution: AVP/Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin are stored in Herring bodies at the axon terminals of the posterior pituitary. They are synthesized by two types of magnocellular neurons in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: AVP binds to V1 receptors on the serosal surface of renal tubular cells
AVP binds to V1 receptors on the luminal surface of renal tubular cells
AVP binds to V2 receptors on the serosal surface of renal tubular cells
AVP binds to V2 receptors on the luminal surface of renal tubular cells

questions.solution:
AVP binds to V2 receptors on the serosal surface (also called basolateral surface) of renal tubular cells.

This interaction activates adenylyl cyclase and leads to the insertion of water channels called aquaporin 2 on the luminal surface of the cell.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ADH is incorrect?

choices.text: It increases aquaporin expression on apical membrane
It increases urine concentration and decreases urine flow
Its secretion occurs when plasma osmolality is low

questions.solution:
ADH secretion reduces when the plasma osmolality becomes low. ADH causes water reabsorption and dilutes the plasma, thereby causing a reduction in plasma osmolality.

The antidiuretic effect of ADH is mediated via a G protein-coupled V2 receptor that increases intracellular cyclic AMP, thereby inducing translocation of aquaporin 2 (AQP 2) water channels into the apical membrane.

During and after surgery, surgical stress results in the release of ADH.

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A mutation in the gene for aquaporin 2 channel leads to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

The antidiuretic hormone (ADH) binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts, and stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal side of the cell membranes.

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a condition in which there is the absence of or poor response to anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This results in reduced permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts to water. This furthermore leads the kidneys to excrete large amounts of dilute urine that clinically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia. 

DI can be of four types : 

Types  Primary pathology Caused by 
Pituitary/ Central DI Primary deficiency of ADH secretion  Mc defect: AVP -Neurophysin II gene
Primary polydipsia



 Suppression of ADH secretion by excessive fluid intake

1. Dipsogenic DI : Following head trauma, TB meningitis, Multiple sclerosis. 
2. Psychogenic DI : Due to psychosis or OCD
3. Iatrogenic polydipsia : Due to motivated health benefits
Gestational DI Deficiency due to Increased degradation of ADH  N terminal aminopeptidase produced by placenta
Nephrogenic DI Renal insensitivity to ADH or drugs or genetic mutation Drugs like lithium - gene encoding V2 receptor on chXq28


Note: Lithium - used to treat bipolar disorder, can cause acquired diabetes insipidus by decreasing the expression of the AQP2 gene. 

Option A : Liddle’s syndrome is due to an inherited gain of function mutation of genes regulating the Na channel in collecting duct ENaC, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. 

Option C : Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutation in CFTR gene that serves as a channel in the luminal plasma membranes of epithelial cells and regulates volume and composition of secretions in exocrine glands.

Option D : Bartter syndrome is due to loss-of-function mutations of transporters and ion channels in thick ascending loop of henle, most commonly, Na-K-2Cl transporter.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would you not expect to see in a patient with Wolfram syndrome?
questions.solution:
Diabetes insipidus is a clinical component of Wolfram syndrome, and not SIADH. 

Characteristics of Wolfram syndrome include:

  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Optic atrophy
  • Sensorineural deafness

(Mnemonic DIDMOAD)

Wolfram syndrome is caused by mutations of the WFS1 gene.

questions.text: All of the following statements about diabetes insipidus are true, except:
questions.solution:
In diabetes insipidus, hypernatremia is observed in the affected patient.

Low levels of vasopressin lead to the excretion of a large amount of diluted urine. This loss of water from the body leads to hypernatremia.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

questions.text: A man presented with frequent urination and increased thirst. Investigations revealed low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. MRI brain was done, which revealed the absence of posterior pituitary bright spot. Which of the following conditions is least likely to lead to this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the absence of a posterior pituitary bright spot on MRI are suggestive of central diabetes insipidus. Multiple sclerosis causes primary polydipsia, not central DI.

Central DI is caused by a primary deficiency in AVP secretion which usually results from agenesis or irreversible destruction of the posterior pituitary. It can be differentiated from primary polydipsia with the help of an MRI brain. 

The MRI given below shows the posterior pituitary bright spot. The arrow points at the posterior pituitary and the arrowhead at the anterior pituitary.

questions.text: A patient presented with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. Investigations revealed 24-hour urine output of 7 litres and low urinary osmolality. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 1.5 pg/ml. Which of the following drugs would not cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Isoniazid is not a potential cause of this condition.

Nephrogenic DI develops due to resistance to the antidiuretic action of AVP. A 24-hour urine volume >3 liters is suggestive of polyuria. An ADH value >1 pg/ml is suggestive of nephrogenic DI. 

International leading endocrinology associations has recommended that the name "diabetes insipidus", in some cases has led to harm, hence the name be changed to reflect the condition's pathophysiology and to eliminate confusion with "diabetes mellitus"
The new proposed names are arginine vasopressin deficiency (AVP-D) for central etiologies and arginine vasopressin resistance (AVP-R) for nephrogenic etiologies.

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria and increased thirst. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. What could be the cause of polyuria in this patient?
questions.solution:
Metabolic derangements like hypercalcemia and hypokalemia lead to the production of large amounts of dilute urine by causing nephrogenic DI.

Options C & D: Primary polydipsia is of three types:

  • Dipsogenic – Due to inappropriate thirst.
  • Iatrogenic – Due to an increase in fluid intake due to its presumed health benefits.
  • Psychogenic – Due to psychosis or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old lady presented with polydipsia and polyuria. Her symptoms started soon after a road traffic accident 6 months ago. Her blood pressure was recorded at 120/80 mmHg with no postural drop. The daily urinary output was reported to be between 6-8 liters. Clinical investigation results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Na = 130 mEq /L 

K = 3.5 mEq/ L

Urea = 15 mg/dl

Sugar = 65 mg/ dl

Plasma osmolality = 268 mOsm/L

Urine osmolality = 45 mOsm/L
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the given clinical scenario would be psychogenic polydipsia.

The normal range of urine osmolality is 500-850 mOsm/L and that of plasma osmolality is 280-295 mOsm/L. Hence in the given scenario, both urine and plasma osmolality are low, along with hyponatremia suggestive of psychogenic polydipsia.

questions.text: A patient presented with polyuria and polydipsia. She has been on lithium therapy for 6 years for bipolar disorder. Investigations revealed low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. Which of the following drugs can be used for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of lithium-induced nephrogenic DI. Among the given options thiazide diuretics is the best suited answer.

Thiazides reduce the kidney’s ability to excrete free water by increasing proximal tubular water reabsorption (secondary to volume contraction) and block the ability of DCT to form dilute urine. This effect results in an increase in urine osmolality.

Treatment of diabetes insipidus:

  • Central and gestational diabetes insipidus:
    • Desmopressin an ADH analog
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus:
    • Adequate water intake along with a low sodium diet 
    • Thiazide diuretics
    • Potassium-sparing diuretics (triamterene and amiloride): Amiloride is the drug of choice for lithium-induced DI
    • Prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (indomethacin)
  • Psychogenic diabetes insipidus:
    • Behavioral therapy to reduce fluid consumption

questions.text: Polyuria characterized by low fixed specific gravity of urine is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Fixed specific gravity, in which values remain 1.010 regardless of fluid intake, occurs in chronic glomerulonephritis with severe renal damage.

In chronic kidney disease, as renal function deteriorates, polyuria can be seen due to the impairment of the kidney's ability to concentrate urine.

In diabetes insipidus, although specific gravity is low it is not fixed.

Potomania (beer potomania/beer drinker's potomania/ beer drinker's hyponatremia) is a specific hypo-osmolality syndrome related to massive consumption of beer.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/ml. An MRI of the brain was performed and T1 weighted indicated the absence of the bright spot. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The features of frequent urination, nocturia, with polyuria(>3L/day), low urine osmolarity(<280 mosm/L), low plasma ADH levels and MRI showing absent pituitary bright spot is suggestive of Pituitary Diabetes Insipidus. 

Diabetes Insipidus(DI) : 

Types  Primary pathology Caused by
Pituitary/ Central DI Primary deficiency of ADH secretion AVP -Neurophysin II gene(most common gene defect)
Primary polydipsia

Suppression of ADH secretion by excessive fluid intake

 

1. Dipsogenic DI : Following head trauma, TB meningitis, Multiple sclerosis. 

2. Psychogenic DI : Due to psychosis or OCD

3. Iatrogenic polydipsia : Due to motivated health benefits
Gestational DI Deficiency due to Increased degradation of ADH 

N terminal aminopeptidase produced by placenta
Nephrogenic DI Renal insensitivity to ADH or drugs like lithium or genetic mutation

defect in gene encoding V2 receptor on chXq28(most common gene defect)

Treatment:

  • For Central DI, synthetic analog of ADH Desmopressin(DDAVP) is used. 
  • For Nephrogenic DI, a low sodium diet with thiazide diuretic and/or amiloride and prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor is used. 
  • For primary polydipsia, there are no effective drugs used but for Iatrogenic type patient education is helpful. 

Other options:

Option A: In nephrogenic DI, there is polyuria, low urine osmolarity but the ADH levels will be >1pg/mL.

Option B: In primary polydipsia, there is polyuria, low urine osmolarity, ADH levels will be <1pg/mL but a pituitary bright spot present.

Option D: In solute loss (mannitol or hypertonic saline infusion), urine osmolality is >300 mOsm/L.
